title: Ticket #5885: enable the schedd to perform job classad transforms upon submission
description:
[ Note: this ticket hopefully replaces #4804 and satisfies #5613 ]

We want the schedd to be able to transform an incoming job classad upon submission. Transformations can be configured via either job_router style route classads, or via the tranform scripting language created for #5805.

The schedd will attempt to apply all job transforms specified by new knob JOB_TRANSFORM_NAMES in order. A job transform should be skipped if a) the transform specified in the config file is not a syntactically valid classad, or b) a requirements expression in the transform ad evaluates to false. Transforms are applied to each newly submitted job in a transaction before the transaction is committed and also before SUBMIT_REQUIREMENTS are checked. Thus, a transform can edit values for either protected or immutable attributes, but an attempt to edit a protected attribute (such as ProcId or Owner) will cause the transform to fail thereby aborting the entire transaction.

See the Remark below for examples and a simple smoke-test.

ToddT suggestions for improvements to documentation (created #5937 for this):

  • Copy syntax from job router section instead of linking to that.
  • Have more references to other parts of the manual (e.g., config knobs).
  • Make sure cases are consistent (to not generate multiple index entries) (e.g., job_route_name?)

  • Add map file to user group example (in comments?).
  • Submit requirements example should require a group.
  • Maybe put complex examples in recipes section of Wiki.
  • Make a link to this from the accounting groups section.

2016-Oct-04 14:38:29 by tannenba:
Here is a simple and fast smoke-test for job transform functionality; this could be the basis for a simple regression test.

First append the following to condor_config and do a condor_reconfig : 

JOB_TRANSFORM_NAMES = BAD ILLEGAL ALWAYS NEVER ALWAYS_NEWSCRIPT
JOB_TRANSFORM_BAD @=end
[
  set_NeverThere3 = "Please work!";
  12foo = asd"as";
  ugh = 7 %$ 8;
]
@end
JOB_TRANSFORM_ILLEGAL @=end
[
  requirements = illegal =?= true;
  set_ProcId = 999;
]
@end
JOB_TRANSFORM_ALWAYS @=end
[
  requirements = True;
  set_AlwaysThere = "Please work!";
  delete_NeverThere2 = true;
  eval_set_OnlyProcZero = ProcId == 0 ? "Please work - proc zero" : "Please work - proc non-zero"
]
@end
JOB_TRANSFORM_NEVER @=end
[
  requirements = False;
  set_NeverThere1 = "Please work!";
]
@end
JOB_TRANSFORM_ALWAYS_NEWSCRIPT @=end
  SET AlwaysThereNew = "Please work!"
  DELETE NeverThereNew
@end

Next, create file test.sub that contains the following job description: 

executable = test.sub
hold = true
+NeverThere2 = "Please work!"
+illegal = $(ILLEGAL:false)
queue 2

Finally, submit as shown below to an empty job queue, and confirm the output is exactly as shown below (i.e. the same output from the grep command, appearing in the same order) : 

C:\condor\test>condor_submit illegal=true test.sub
Submitting job(s)..
ERROR: Failed to commit job submission into the queue.
ERROR: Failed to apply a required job transform.


C:\condor\test>condor_submit test.sub
Submitting job(s)..
2 job(s) submitted to cluster 280.

C:\condor\test>condor_q -l | grep Please
AlwaysThere = "Please work!"
AlwaysThereNew = "Please work!"
OnlyProcZero = "Please work - proc zero"
AlwaysThere = "Please work!"
AlwaysThereNew = "Please work!"
OnlyProcZero = "Please work - proc non-zero"

C:\condor\test>
